ABSTRAC T

Aiming at improving anticorrosive protection methods, researchers have turned their attention to research in the area of coating with a hydrophobic character due to its ability to repel aqueous electrolytes. This property gives the coating a greater barrier efficiency and, consequently, a better anticorrosive property. The present work was developed with the purpose of investigating and improving the hydrophobic character of an epoxy paint pigmented with niobium pentoxide. Prelim inary contact angle measurement tests indicated that the paint surface is naturally hydrophilic, as it has values less than 90¬∫. Thus, to give the paint a hydrophobic character, heating was applied after the curing time at different temperatures. The bes t contact angle measurement result, around 98¬∞, was obtained at temperature of 60¬∞C. In addition to good hydrophobicity results, the material heated to 60¬∞C also demonstrated an improvement in the impedance result in relation to the sample without heating, having the first reaching an impedance modulus in low frequencies on the scale of approximately 1010, while the material without heating came to the value of roughly 108. After setting the heating temperature, eight samples were taken to an oven at 60¬∫C, and electrochemical impedance analyzes and contact angle measurements were performed after taking a sample from the oven hourly of heating, totalling eight hours of testing, and the results indicated that a six -hour warm -up time was most appropriate. The c haracterization of the material surface through optical microscopy and scanning electron microscopy (MEV) revealed that after heating, the material surface became more compact and with a possible decrease in porosity concerning the unheated sample. The polarization results showed that the heated material presented a lower corrosion current, indicating more excellent polarization resistance than, which corroborates the hypothesis of a decrease in the material's porosity observed at MEV. The immersion analysi s, performed in 3.5%m/v NaCl solution for thirty days, also indicated that the heating process gave the paint an improvement in its barrier property in contact with a 3.5%w/v NaCl aqueous solution. Through the tests carried out, it was possible to verify t hat heating at 60¬∫C for six hours enabled an improvement in the barrier property offered by the paint and an improvement in the hydrophobic character of the paint.
Keywords: Paint; Niobium pentoxide; hydrophobicity; corrosion.
